docs.lead_paragraph: History remembers the pianist Ignace Paderewski as a virtuoso, a gifted composer and a statesman. Mutual of New York remembers him as a darned good insurance risk. In 1921, Paderewski, then 61 and living in Paso Robles, Calif., applied for a $50,000 policy, and an investigator was assigned to report on his health, habits and net worth. The report to New York couldn't have been more satisfactory. Paderewski earned about $200,000 a year and spent money "very freely." How freely? "I might mention that when he goes to the 'movies' in Paso Robles, he pays them $20 not to play the organ while he is there."
